questions.text: In fetal alcohol syndrome, which of the following is not seen? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Macrocephaly

 

  • Fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS) is associated with microcephaly, not macrocephaly.

 

 

Fetal Alcohol Syndrome (FAS) is a condition that arises from excessive alcohol exposure during pregnancy, which leads to a range of developmental abnormalities. FAS is characterized by several key features, including facial anomalies, central nervous system (CNS) dysfunction, and growth deficiencies.

 

  • Facial Anomalies: The classic facial features of FAS include small eye openings (narrow palpebral fissures), a smooth philtrum (the area between the nose and upper lip), and a thin upper lip. Other features may include epicanthic folds, a flattened nasal bridge, a short nose, low-set and unparallel ears, and midfacial hypoplasia.
  • CNS Dysfunction: This includes microcephaly (small head size), mental retardation, and neurobehavioral abnormalities such as attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). The presence of microcephaly is a common finding in FAS, reflecting the overall poor brain growth and development.
  • Thinning of Corpus Callosum: FAS can lead to structural brain abnormalities such as thinning or complete agenesis of the corpus callosum, which is the band of nerve fibers that connects the two hemispheres of the brain.
  • Holoprosencephaly: This is a severe brain malformation where the forebrain fails to divide into two hemispheres, which can be seen in more severe cases of FAS.

 

Macrocephaly (enlarged head size) is not a feature of FAS. On the contrary, FAS is typically associated with microcephaly, reflecting the impaired brain growth caused by alcohol exposure during pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thinning of corpus callosum: This is a known CNS abnormality in FAS, reflecting the significant impact of alcohol on brain structure and development.

 

Option B. Microcephaly: One of the hallmark features of FAS, microcephaly indicates reduced brain size and development, commonly seen in affected infants.

 

Option C. Holoprosencephaly: This severe brain malformation can occur in the context of FAS, particularly in cases where the alcohol exposure has profoundly disrupted early brain development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fetal Alcohol Syndrome (FAS) is associated with microcephaly and other CNS abnormalities, but macrocephaly is not a feature of this condition.

questions.text: A woman came to OPD with a newborn who has complaints of chest retractions, dyspnea, and lethargy. The paediatrician diagnosed the baby with respiratory distress syndrome. This occurs due to the deficiency of: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lecithin

 

Newborn is suffering from respiratory distress syndrome which is due to surfactant deficiency, i.e., lecithin.

 

Respiratory Distress Syndrome (Hyaline Membrane Disease)

 

 

The newborn is suffering from respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), also known as hyaline membrane disease, which is primarily caused by a deficiency of surfactant. Surfactant is crucial for reducing surface tension within the alveoli, preventing their collapse, and maintaining proper lung function. Lecithin, also known as dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine (DPPC), is the most important component of surfactant. A deficiency in lecithin leads to insufficient surfactant production, resulting in alveolar collapse, reduced functional residual capacity (FRC), and the clinical features observed in RDS.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Dipalmitoyl inositol: This is not a component of surfactant. The main components of surfactant are phospholipids like lecithin and other proteins.

 

Option C. Sphingomyelin: While present in amniotic fluid and used in the lecithin/sphingomyelin (L/S) ratio to assess fetal lung maturity, it is not the primary component of surfactant.

 

Option D. Dipalmitoyl phosphatidylethanolamine: This is a phospholipid but not a primary component of surfactant involved in preventing alveolar collapse.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Respiratory distress syndrome in newborns is primarily caused by a deficiency of surfactant, particularly lecithin (dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine).

questions.text: What is the rate of increment of head circumference in the first three months of life?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 cm per month

 

During the first three months of life, the head circumference of a baby increases by approximately 2 cm per month. This rapid growth is due to the significant brain development occurring during this period. After the first three months, the growth rate slows down. From three to six months of age, the head circumference increases by about 1 cm per month, and from six months to one year, it increases by about 0.5 cm per month.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The head circumference of a baby increases by approximately 2 cm per month during the first three months of life.

choices.text: Give oral fluids and zinc supplementation only and ask mother to come back if danger sign develops.
Give oral fluids and ask mother to continue the same and visit again the next day.
Consider severe dehydration start IV fluids, IV antibiotics, and refer to higher centre.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child was brought to the hospital with a history of loose stools. No history of fever or blood in stools. The mother says he is irritable and eagerly drinks water if given. On examination, eyes are sunken and in the skin pinch test, the skin retracted within two seconds but not immediately. What treatment is advised for the child? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Give oral fluids and zinc supplementation only and ask mother to come back if danger sign develops

 

In this question, the child has some dehydration because he or she is restless and irritable, drinks water freely, has sluggish skin retraction (2 seconds) on skin pinch test, and has sunken eyes.

 

Treatment according to the WHO Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Diseases (IMNCI) guideline plan B.

 

  • Oral rehydration therapy
  • Zinc supplements,
  • Sustained breastfeeding

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Give oral fluids and ask mother to continue the same and visit again the next day: Zinc supplementation is an important treatment protocol for diarrhea. In this option that point was missing, therefore this is not the right option.

 

Option C. Consider severe dehydration start IV fluids, IV antibiotics, and refer to higher centre: If the child was having refusal to drink with skin pinch more than 2 seconds, we could have thought of severe dehydration. Therefore this is not the right option.

 

Option D. Wait and observe: Child is eagerly drinking which is a feature of some dehydration, therefore, wait and observe is not the right option.

 

Educational Objective:


In a child with some dehydration, the recommended treatment includes oral rehydration therapy, zinc supplementation, and continued breastfeeding, with instructions to return if danger signs develop.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is evaluated by her pediatrician due to decreased urine output. She weighs 22 kg and measures 115 cm tall. Laboratory tests show a blood urea level of 50 mg/dL and a serum creatinine of 0.8 mg/dL. To assess her kidney function, her doctor plans to calculate the estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) using the Schwartz formula. What is the calculated eGFR for this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 60 mL/min/1.73 m²
 

 

The Schwartz formula is a widely used method to estimate the glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) in children. It utilizes the child’s height, serum creatinine level, and a constant specific to their age group. For children between the ages of 1 and 16, the constant k is set at 0.413.

 

The formula is as follows:
 

 

In this case:

Height = 115 cm

Serum creatinine = 0.8 mg/dL

Constant k = 0.413

 

 

The calculated eGFR of approximately 59.3 mL/min/1.73 m² is closest to option C, which is 60 mL/min/1.73 m². This result indicates mild to moderate renal impairment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Schwartz formula is commonly used to estimate eGFR in pediatric patients. It takes into account the child's height and serum creatinine. For children aged 1 to 16 years, the constant k is 0.413. Accurate calculation of eGFR helps in assessing kidney function and determining the severity of renal impairment.

questions.text: An 8-day-old newborn was found to have thyroid -stimulating hormone level of more than 100 mlU/L. Which of the following will be the next best investigation? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Radiotracer uptake with technetium

 

The classical presentation is described as the 6 P's of congenital hypothyroidism: pot-belly, pale, puffy-faced child with protruding umbilicus, protuberant tongue, and poor brain development and persistent opening of posterior fontanelle, prolong jaundice & hypotonia.

 

The given laboratory finding of increased thyroid-stimulating hormone level in an 8-day-old baby is suggestive of congenital hypothyroidism. Radiotracer uptake with technetium will be the next investigation in this condition to confirm the presence of the thyroid gland.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Urine iodine excretion: This test measures the iodine content in urine and is typically used to assess iodine deficiency in populations rather than diagnosing congenital hypothyroidism in an individual.

 

Option B. Serum thyroid receptor antibody: This test is more relevant in diagnosing autoimmune thyroid diseases such as Graves' disease rather than congenital hypothyroidism.

 

Option D. Perchlorate secretion test: This test is used to identify a defect in thyroid hormone synthesis, particularly in conditions like thyroid dyshormonogenesis, but it is not the first-line investigation for a neonate with high TSH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Radiotracer uptake with technetium is the next best investigation to confirm the presence and function of the thyroid gland in a newborn with elevated TSH.

questions.text: A baby is brought to OPD for 10-week DPT vaccination appointment. He previously experienced a fever exceeding 40°C and had an inconsolable cry at 6 weeks old after receiving a vaccination. What would be the recommended course of action moving forward? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Give DT vaccine

 

The child experienced a hypotonic-hyporesponsive episode or severe reaction (fever >40°C and persistent inconsolable crying) after the previous DPT dose. These are precautionary (not absolute contraindications) for pertussis-containing vaccines like DPT, but they warrant switching to a less reactogenic formulation.

 

DT (Diphtheria + Tetanus) vaccine is recommended in such cases, as it omits the pertussis component, which is most often responsible for such adverse events.

 

This allows continuation of diphtheria and tetanus protection while avoiding further adverse events from the pertussis component.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Avoid DPT vaccination: Incorrect. DPT is contraindicated, but not all vaccinations should be avoided. The child should still receive protection against diphtheria and tetanus.

 

Option C. Give DPT vaccine: Incorrect. Given the prior adverse reaction, repeating DPT may risk more serious reactions. It’s prudent to avoid the pertussis component.

 

Option D. Defer by 4 weeks: Incorrect. There's no benefit in deferring the dose. The issue is not timing but the component that caused the reaction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe reactions (such as high fever >40.5°C, persistent inconsolable crying >3 hours, or hypotonic-hyporesponsive episodes) after a previous DPT dose are indications to withhold the pertussis component in future doses. The child should receive the DT vaccine instead.

choices.text: Nile blue test showing >50% of blue cells

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indicator of fetal lung maturity? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nile blue test showing >50% of blue cells

 

The Nile blue test is a laboratory test used to assess fetal lung maturity by staining desquamated fetal cells obtained from amniotic fluid. The correct interpretation of this test is that if more than 50% of the cells stain orange, it indicates pulmonary maturity. Therefore, the presence of more than 50% blue cells, as mentioned in Option D, suggests immature lungs rather than maturity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lecithin-sphingomyelin ratio > 2.0: The Lecithin-sphingomyelin (L/S) ratio is a well-established method for assessing fetal lung maturity. A ratio greater than 2.0 typically indicates mature fetal lungs.

 

Option B. Positive shake test: The shake test, also known as the foam stability test, assesses the presence of surfactant in amniotic fluid. A positive shake test, indicated by the formation of stable bubbles, suggests fetal lung maturity.

 

Option C. Increased phosphatidyl glycerol: The presence of phosphatidylglycerol in amniotic fluid is another indicator of lung maturity, particularly in pregnancies complicated by diabetes.

 

Educational Objective:


The presence of more than 50% orange cells in the Nile blue test indicates fetal lung maturity, whereas more than 50% blue cells suggest immaturity.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old child presents with altered sensorium, persistent headache, and photophobia for the past 5 days. On examination, he has signs of meningeal irritation. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis reveals:what is your diagnosis?
Protein: 93 mg/dL


Glucose: 20 mg/dL (serum glucose = 90 mg/dL)


Cell count: Predominantly lymphocytic pleocytosis (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tubercular meningitis

 

  • Tubercular meningitis is often associated with CSF findings of elevated protein, decreased glucose, and lymphocytic pleocytosis. These findings are consistent with the given CSF results.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bacterial meningitis: The CSF findings of elevated protein, decreased glucose, and an increased number of neutrophil predominance (not lymphocytes) are suggestive of meningitis. However, bacterial meningitis is more commonly associated with a significantly higher white blood cell count (pleocytosis) in the CSF. The given CSF results are not typical for bacterial meningitis.

 

Option B. Viral meningitis: This is a potential consideration. Viral meningitis can present with elevated protein, normal or mildly reduced glucose, and an increased number of lymphocytes in the CSF. It is a common cause of aseptic (non-bacterial) meningitis.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A child transfers an object from one hand to another. What does it signify? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ability to compare objects

 

When a child transfers an object from one hand to another, it signifies their ability to compare objects. This milestone typically occurs around 5.5 to 6 months of age. At this stage, the child is beginning to understand the differences between objects, which is why they are capable of transferring an object between hands. This action demonstrates the child's growing cognitive ability to recognize and compare different objects, an important part of early development.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Visual motor coordination: Visual motor coordination refers to the ability to use the eyes and hands together to perform tasks, such as reaching for and grasping objects. While this is important for transferring objects, the key developmental significance of transferring an object from one hand to another lies in the child's ability to compare objects.

 

Option C. Ability to handle small objects: The ability to handle small objects, such as developing a pincer grasp, occurs later, typically around 8 to 9 months of age. This milestone involves more fine motor control and precision, which is different from the broader action of transferring objects between hands.

 

Option D. Voluntary release: Voluntary release refers to the ability to let go of an object intentionally, which is generally seen after the palmar grasp reflex disappears around 4 to 6 months. However, the act of transferring an object from one hand to another is more about the child’s ability to compare objects rather than just releasing them.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transferring an object from one hand to another in a child signifies their developing ability to compare objects, a cognitive milestone typically reached around 5.5 to 6 months of age.

 

Developmental Milestones in 1st Yr of Life

questions.text: Which one of the following is not a feature in cerebral palsy? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Flaccid paralysis

 

Flaccid paralysis is not a feature of cerebral palsy (CP). It is a feature of lower motor neuron disease.

 

Cerebral palsy is characterized by abnormalities in muscle tone and movement, including -

 

  • Hypertonia (increased muscle tone),
  • Hypotonia (decreased muscle tone),
  • Ataxia (lack of muscle coordination) is also commonly observed in individuals with cerebral palsy.
  • A deficit in the motor, language, and social milestones
  • Microcephaly is a feature of cerebral palsy because of the insult to the developing brain.
  • It is an upper motor neuron disease characterized by rigidity and scissoring gait.
  • Spastic CP is the commonest type (65%)

 

Seen in conditions such as Guillain-Barré syndrome, transverse myelitis, poliomyelitis, and traumatic neuritis, but not typically in cerebral palsy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypotonia: Can be present in cerebral palsy, characterized by low muscle tone.

 

Option B. Microcephaly: Often associated with cerebral palsy due to brain injury or developmental issues.

 

Option C. Ataxia: Characterized by poor balance and coordination, is a common feature of certain types of cerebral palsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Flaccid paralysis is not a feature of cerebral palsy; it is indicative of lower motor neuron disease. Cerebral palsy is characterized by various forms of muscle tone abnormalities and movement disorders.

choices.text: Adenosine deaminase deficiency

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with delayed motor development, mental retardation, and finger biting. Initially normal at birth, the child later develops cerebral palsy, arthritis, and dies from renal failure at age 25. Which enzyme deficiency is most likely? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. HGPRT deficiency

 

The described symptoms are indicative of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, which is caused by a complete deficiency of the enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT). This X-linked recessive disorder is characterized by hyperuricemia, self-mutilative behavior, choreoathetosis, spasticity, and mental retardation. The enzyme deficiency leads to overproduction of uric acid, causing complications like gouty arthritis, uric acid crystalluria, nephrolithiasis, and obstructive uropathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hexosaminidase deficiency - Associated with Tay-Sachs disease, characterized by neurodegeneration but not self-mutilation or hyperuricemia.

 

Option B. Adenosine deaminase deficiency - Leads to severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID), characterized by severe immunodeficiency.

 

Option D. Ornithine transcarbamoylase deficiency - A urea cycle disorder presenting with hyperammonemia but not with the neurological and behavioral symptoms described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, caused by HGPRT deficiency, leads to hyperuricemia, self-mutilative behavior, and neurological symptoms, often resulting in severe complications like renal failure.

questions.text: Which can be used as an alternative to breast milk in low birth weight (LBW) child? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Human donor milk

 

  • Human donor milk is the alternative to breast milk in low birth weight infants
  • Low birth weight refers to birth weight less than 2500 grams due to preterm birth or intrauterine growth restriction or both
  • All low birth weight babies should be fed only by breast milk, regardless of the feeding method
  • Expressed breast milk or human donor milk should be given to infants fed by paladai or gastric tube

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Preterm formula & Option C. Term formula: Formula feeds, including term formula feed for infants weighing ≥1500 g at birth and preterm formula feed for very low birth weight infants, can be given when there is a contraindication to breastfeeding or if the mother is sick or human donor milk is not available or toned milk is not available.

 

Option A. Cow milk: Cow milk is not given because it is rich in casein. Casein causes constipation, colicky pain and cow milk protein allergy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Human donor milk is the alternative to breast milk in low birth weight infants

questions.text: A 2-day-old neonate was admitted to the NICU after he was observed to have movements as shown in the image. His APGAR scores were 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. His blood sugar was within the normal range in the first 24 hours. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Focal clonic seizure.

 

The movements depicted in the clip are indicative of a focal clonic seizure. In neonates, focal clonic seizures are characterized by multiple, repetitive, rhythmic contractions of muscle groups. These contractions can involve the limbs, face, or trunk. Key characteristics of focal clonic seizures include:

 

  1. Unifocal or multifocal: The seizure may involve muscle groups on one side of the body (unifocal) or multiple regions (multifocal).
  2. Synchronous or asynchronous: The movements can occur either in a coordinated manner (synchronously) or in an uncoordinated manner (asynchronously) across different muscle groups.
  3. Resistant to restraint: The movements are involuntary and cannot be suppressed by restraining the affected limb or body part.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Focal tonic seizure: In contrast to focal clonic seizures, focal tonic seizures involve sustained posturing of a single limb, asymmetrical trunk posturing, or sustained ocular deviation. These postures are not influenced by external stimulation or restraint.

 

Option C. Spasms: Neonatal spasms are characterized by sudden, generalized jerks that last approximately 1-2 seconds. These spasms often occur in clusters and can be classified as flexor, extensor, or a combination of both. Unlike clonic seizures, spasms are not triggered or suppressed by stimulation or restraint.

 

Option D. Subtle seizure: Subtle seizures in neonates may present with less noticeable symptoms such as eye deviations, nystagmus, blinking, mouthing movements, or abnormal extremity motions (e.g., rowing, swimming, cycling). Other signs may include changes in heart rate, episodes of hypertension, or apnea. These seizures are more common in premature infants.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Focal clonic seizures in neonates involve repetitive, rhythmic contractions of muscle groups that are resistant to restraint and can be unifocal or multifocal.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are independently false statements.
The assertion is independently a true statement, but the reason is independently a false statement.
Both assertion and reason are independently true statements, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion.
Both assertion and reason are independently true statements, and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion.

questions.text:
Choose the most appropriate answer: (INICET NOV 2022)

 

Assertion: In phenylketonuria, the urine has a mousy odor.

 

Reason: The serum levels of tyrosine, dopamine, and norepinephrine are decreased in phenylketonuria.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both assertion and reason are independently true statements, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion.

 

  • Assertion: The statement that "In phenylketonuria, the urine has a mousy odor" is true. The mousy or musty odor of the urine in phenylketonuria (PKU) is due to the accumulation of phenylacetate, one of the metabolites of phenylalanine.
  • Reason: The statement that "The serum levels of tyrosine, dopamine, and norepinephrine are decreased in phenylketonuria" is also true. Phenylketonuria is characterized by a deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase, which converts phenylalanine to tyrosine. Consequently, low levels of tyrosine lead to reduced synthesis of catecholamines such as dopamine, norepinephrine, and epinephrine.

 

However, the reason provided is not the correct explanation for the assertion. The mousy odor in PKU is directly related to the accumulation of phenylacetate, not to the decreased levels of tyrosine or catecholamines.

 

Detailed Mechanism:

 

  • Phenylketonuria (PKU): PKU is an inborn error of metabolism caused by a deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase or, less commonly, a defect in enzymes responsible for producing tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4). This defect results in impaired conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine, leading to the accumulation of phenylalanine and its metabolites, such as phenylpyruvate and phenylacetate, which are excreted in the urine.
  • Tyrosine and Catecholamine Synthesis: Tyrosine is a precursor for the synthesis of catecholamines, including dopamine, norepinephrine, and epinephrine. In PKU, the deficiency of tyrosine leads to reduced synthesis of these neurotransmitters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In phenylketonuria, the mousy odor of urine is due to the accumulation of phenylacetate, while decreased levels of tyrosine and catecholamines are a result of the impaired conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine. However, the two phenomena are not causally related.

questions.text: A child with infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis has multiple episodes of non-bilious vomiting. Which of the following metabolic abnormalities is likely to be seen in this condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypochloremic, hypokalemic alkalosis

 

Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS) is a condition where there is constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet due to hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the pylorus. This results in persistent vomiting, which leads to the loss of hydrogen and chloride ions in the gastric acid and potassium ions in the gastric mucus. As a consequence, the multiple episodes of non-bilious vomiting in IHPS can cause hypochloremia and hypokalemia, leading to alkalosis.

 

Cause of metabolic alkalosis: The hydrogen ions that normally reach the duodenum are now lost due to vomiting. Hence, the bicarbonate secretion from the pancreas is decreased, thereby increasing the bicarbonate levels in the serum.

 

Causes of hypokalemia:

 

  • Because of alkalosis, the hydrogen ions exit from the cells in exchange for potassium leading to hypokalemia.
  • Loss of fluid due to excessive vomiting activates the RAAS pathway. This worsens hypokalemia as the aldosterone causes active reabsorption of sodium in exchange for the secretion of K* and H* ions into the urine. The loss of H* ions in urine lowers the urinary pH, resulting in paradoxical aciduria

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis leads to hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis due to persistent vomiting and loss of gastric acid.

choices.text: Early discharge, skin to skin contact, prevent infection
Early discharge, skin to skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding
Skin to skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding, prevent infection
Early discharge, exclusive breastfeeding and prevent infection

questions.text: Which of the following are components of kangaroo mother care? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Early discharge, skin to skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding.

 

Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC) is an essential practice for the care of low birthweight infants, particularly in resource-limited settings. The core components of KMC include:

 

  • Skin-to-skin contact: The baby is placed between the mother's breasts in an upright position. The baby's hips are abducted and flexed in a "frog position," and the arms are also flexed. This close contact helps regulate the baby's temperature, breathing, and heart rate.
  • Exclusive breastfeeding: KMC promotes exclusive breastfeeding, which is crucial for the baby's nutrition and immune protection.
  • Early discharge and ambulatory care: KMC supports the early discharge of stable low birthweight infants from the hospital, allowing continued care at home with close follow-up.

 

These components are fundamental to the success of KMC, leading to improved survival rates and health outcomes for low birthweight infants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Early discharge, skin to skin contact, prevent infection: Includes "prevent infection," which is an essential aspect of general neonatal care but not a specific component of KMC. KMC primarily focuses on skin-to-skin contact, breastfeeding, and early discharge.

 

Option C. Skin to skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding, prevent infection: Also mentions "prevent infection," which, while important, is not a direct component of KMC.

 

Option D. Early discharge, exclusive breastfeeding and prevent infection: Includes "prevent infection" instead of "skin-to-skin contact," making it incorrect, as skin-to-skin contact is a critical element of KMC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC) involves skin-to-skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding, and early discharge, focusing on the care of low birthweight infants.

questions.text: An 18-month-old baby was brought to the hospital with complaints of poor feeding and abnormal twitching of his lower limb. On examination, he has fever with fontanelle bulging and the child was lethargic. The most probable cause is: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Meningitis

 

Poor eating, fever, convulsions, a bulging fontanelle, and lethargy are all symptoms of meningitis.

 

Meningococcus, Streptococcus pneumonia, or Haemophilus influenza type b can all cause bacterial meningitis. General symptoms include fever, lethargy, unwillingness to feed, vomiting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Febrile seizure: Patient should have a history of high grade fever associated with seizures.

 

Option C. Pseudotumor cerebri: This is the most common type of focal seizure present in sleep. Age group 3-10 yr, resolve by adolescence. Start at night in the form of buccal throat tingling, tonic clonic contraction of one side with preserved consciousness.

 

Option D. Intracranial hemorrhage: Patient should have history of any trauma

 

Seizures and localised neurological symptoms are possible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Poor eating, fever, convulsions, a bulging fontanelle, and lethargy are all symptoms of meningitis.

questions.text:
Which of the following are causes of neonatal seizures? (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Hyponatremia
  2. Hypomagnesemia
  3. Hypocalcemia
  4. Hypernatremia
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3 and 4

 

All of the above-given options- hyponatremia, hypomagnesemia, hypocalcemia, and hypernatremia are causes of neonatal seizures.

 

Metabolic disorders cause neonatal seizures commonly. Hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy is the most common cause.

 

 

Neonatal seizures may be of five types: subtle, tonic, clonic, spasms, and myoclonic.

 

  • Subtle seizures include movements like transient eye deviations, nystagmus, blinking, mouthing, rowing, cycling, pedaling, fluctuations in heart rate, hypertension episodes, and apnea. They are more common in premature than in term babies.
  • Tonic seizures are characterized by increased tension in the muscle groups. They may be focal or generalized.
    • Focal tonic seizures are characterized by sustained posturing of a single limb, sustained asymmetrical posturing of the trunk, and sustained eye deviation. They can not be provoked by stimulation or suppressed by restraint.
    • Generalized tonic seizures occur as bilateral tonic limb extensions or flexions of the upper limbs often accompanied by a tonic extension of the lower limbs and trunk.
  • A clonic seizure is characterized by multiple, repetitive, rhythmic contractions of muscle groups. Muscles of the limbs, face, or trunk can be involved. They can be unifocal or multifocal. It cannot be suppressed by restraint.
  • Spasms are sudden generalized jerks lasting 1-2 sec and are usually associated with a single, very brief, generalized discharge. They may be flexor, extensor, or mixed extensor/flexor and can occur in clusters. It cannot be provoked by stimulation or suppressed by restraint.
  • Myoclonic seizures can be focal, multifocal, or generalized. They are differentiated from clonic seizures by their lack of rhythmicity and the rapidity of the jerks (<50 msec).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neonatal seizures can be caused by various metabolic disturbances, including hyponatremia, hypomagnesemia, hypocalcemia, and hypernatremia, and these should be considered in the differential diagnosis of seizures in neonates.

questions.text: The procedure displayed below is? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Orogastric tube insertion.

 

The procedure depicted in the image is orogastric tube insertion. This involves placing a tube through the mouth (orally) and advancing it down into the stomach. Orogastric tubes are commonly used in pediatric patients for several purposes:

 

  • Enteral rehydration: In children with mild-to-moderate dehydration, an orogastric tube can be used to facilitate enteral rehydration, allowing for fluid administration directly into the stomach.
  • Nutritional support: For children who are severely ill or have significant dehydration, orogastric tubes can also be used for nutritional support by delivering necessary nutrients and medications directly to the stomach.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intubation: Intubation involves placing a tube into the trachea to maintain an open airway and is primarily used in situations where airway protection or mechanical ventilation is required. This is not the procedure shown in the image.

 

Option B. Nasogastric tube insertion: Nasogastric tube insertion is similar to orogastric tube insertion, but the tube is inserted through the nose instead of the mouth. While both procedures aim to reach the stomach, the entry point distinguishes them.

 

Option D. Oropharyngeal airway insertion: Oropharyngeal airways are devices inserted into the mouth to prevent the tongue from obstructing the airway, usually during anesthesia or in unconscious patients. This is not the procedure shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Orogastric tube insertion involves placing a tube through the mouth into the stomach and is used for rehydration and nutritional support in pediatric patients, particularly those with dehydration or severe illness.

choices.text: Weight for height less than -3 SD
Weight for age less than -3 SD

questions.text: Which of the following is not a criteria for severe acute malnutrition? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Weight for age less than -3 SD

 

Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) is a serious health condition in children that requires urgent attention. The World Health Organization (WHO) defines SAM based on specific criteria, which are indicators of a child's nutritional status and risk of mortality.

 

Criteria for Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM):

 

  • Weight for height less than -3 SD (Standard Deviations)
  • Mid-Upper Arm Circumference (MUAC) < 11.5 mm
  • Bilateral Pedal Edema

 

However, Weight for age less than -3 SD is not a criterion for diagnosing severe acute malnutrition. While weight-for-age is a measure used to assess growth and general nutritional status, it does not specifically define SAM. Instead, weight-for-age is more indicative of general undernutrition or stunting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe acute malnutrition is defined by weight-for-height less than -3 SD, MUAC < 115 mm, or the presence of bilateral pedal edema, but not by weight-for-age less than -3 SD.

questions.text: A newborn is found to have hepatomegaly during a routine examination, with no other significant findings. Investigations reveal positive Anti-HCMV antibodies. What long-term condition is this child at risk for? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Sensorineural hearing loss

 

Positive human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) antibodies at birth indicate congenital CMV infection. While symptomatic congenital CMV infection can lead to severe complications like mental retardation, even asymptomatic infections pose a risk of sensorineural hearing loss in about 7-10% of cases. This hearing loss can occur even in the absence of other symptoms at birth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Renal failure - Not a typical sequela of congenital CMV infection.

 

Option B. Mental retardation - More common in symptomatic cases, not asymptomatic cases.

 

Option C. Hepatic fibrosis - Not commonly associated with congenital CMV infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Asymptomatic congenital CMV infection significantly increases the risk of developing sensorineural hearing loss later in life.

questions.text: Two girls in the same class are diagnosed with meningococcal meningitis. Their 12-year-old friend from the same school is afraid of contracting the disease. What advice should be given to the exposed students? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Antibiotic prophylaxis

 

The best advice for the exposed students is to receive antibiotic prophylaxis. This is recommended for close contacts of a person with meningococcal meningitis, such as household members, intimate contacts, and anyone who has had direct contact with the patient's oral secretions. Antibiotic prophylaxis should be initiated as soon as possible after exposure and can be effective in preventing secondary cases of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Two doses of polysaccharide vaccine: While vaccination is important, it takes time to provide protection. Therefore, it is not the best option for immediate protection in this situation.

 

Option C. Two doses of conjugate vaccine: The conjugate vaccine is recommended for adolescents and children, but similar to the polysaccharide vaccine, it does not provide immediate protection. Antibiotic prophylaxis is still necessary for those who have been exposed.

 

Option D. Single dose of meningococcal vaccine: Again, vaccination alone is not sufficient for immediate protection, and antibiotic prophylaxis is necessary for those who have been exposed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For immediate protection after exposure to meningococcal meningitis, antibiotic prophylaxis is necessary. Vaccination is also recommended but does not provide immediate protection.

questions.text: A 1-day old neonate presented with scaphoid abdomen, respiratory distress and mediastinal shift. All of the following can be done except? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bag and mask ventilation

 

Bag and mask ventilation can be challenging and less effective in the presence of a scaphoid abdomen and mediastinal shift. In such cases, positive pressure ventilation through an endotracheal tube or a ventilator may be more appropriate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. O2 by mask: This is a valid intervention. Providing oxygen by mask can be an initial step to improve oxygenation in a neonate with respiratory distress. The goal is to support oxygenation until more definitive measures can be taken.

 

Option B. Positive pressure ventilation by ventilator: This is a valid intervention. Positive pressure ventilation with a ventilator may be necessary in cases of severe respiratory distress or failure. It helps to provide adequate oxygenation and ventilation to the neonate.

 

Option C. ET intubation: This is a valid intervention. Endotracheal (ET) intubation may be indicated in cases where positive pressure ventilation is required or to secure the airway in the presence of respiratory distress.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the clinical signs of diaphragmatic hernia, such as a scaphoid abdomen, respiratory distress, and mediastinal shift. Understand the appropriate interventions, including oxygen administration, positive pressure ventilation, endotracheal intubation, and the limitations of bag and mask ventilation in specific clinical scenarios.

choices.text: There is hypertrophy of ductus arteriosus.
Coarctation distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery
Supply is from posterior to anterior thoracic artery.
Collaterals develop to supply upper limb.

questions.text: A child presents with cold feet and a history of wearing socks even in the summers. On examination, lower limb pulses are diminished as compared to the radial pulse. Prominent radio femoral delay is present. What is the underlying condition? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coarctation distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery

 

The clinical presentation of cold feet, wearing socks even in summer, diminished lower limb pulses compared to radial pulses, and prominent radiofemoral delay is characteristic of coarctation of the aorta. This congenital condition is characterized by a narrowing (coarctation) of the aorta, typically just distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery at the ductus arteriosus.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Coarctation of the Aorta: This condition results in the obstruction of blood flow, leading to higher blood pressure in the upper limbs and lower blood pressure in the lower limbs. The radiofemoral delay is a classic sign.
  • Location of Coarctation:
    • Postductal Coarctation (Adult Type): The constriction occurs distal to the ductus arteriosus. This type is more common and leads to the development of collateral circulation to bypass the obstruction.
    • Predductal Coarctation (Infantile Type): The constriction occurs proximal to the ductus arteriosus, leading to different clinical features and often presenting in infancy.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Cold feet and preference for wearing socks may be due to poor perfusion in the lower extremities.
    • Diminished lower limb pulses and radiofemoral delay are hallmark signs.
    • Hypertension in the upper extremities due to the coarctation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypertrophy of ductus arteriosus: This condition does not cause radiofemoral delay or the constellation of symptoms seen in coarctation of the aorta.

 

Option C. Supply from posterior to anterior thoracic artery: This does not explain the clinical presentation, especially the radiofemoral delay.

 

Option D. Collaterals develop to supply upper limb: Collateral circulation is a compensatory mechanism that develops over time in coarctation of the aorta, primarily to supply blood to the lower extremities, not just the upper limbs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coarctation of the aorta typically presents with cold feet, diminished lower limb pulses, and radiofemoral delay due to a narrowing of the aorta distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery.

questions.text: Drug resistance is seen in which of the following STDs:  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gonorrhea

 

Gonorrhea, caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae, has exhibited significant drug resistance over the years. Initially, penicillin was the treatment of choice for gonorrhea. However, the emergence of penicillin-resistant strains necessitated a shift to other antibiotics. Fluoroquinolones were subsequently used, but resistance to these agents also developed. Currently, third-generation cephalosporins, such as ceftriaxone, are the recommended treatment. The issue of antibiotic resistance in Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a major public health concern, and ongoing surveillance and development of new treatments are crucial.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Syphilis: Syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum, has not shown significant drug resistance. It remains highly sensitive to penicillin, which is still the first-line treatment for all stages of syphilis.

 

Option B. Chancroid: Chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, has not shown widespread drug resistance. It is typically treated with azithromycin, ceftriaxone, ciprofloxacin, or erythromycin.

 

Option C. Donovanosis: Donovanosis, caused by Klebsiella granulomatis, is treated with antibiotics such as azithromycin, doxycycline, ciprofloxacin, or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Drug resistance is not a significant issue with donovanosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neisseria gonorrhoeae, the causative agent of gonorrhea, has developed resistance to multiple antibiotics, including penicillin and fluoroquinolones, making third-generation cephalosporins the current treatment of choice.

choices.text: Low mechanical fragility, high osmotic fragility
High mechanical fragility, high osmotic fragility
Low mechanical fragility, low osmotic fragility
High mechanical fragility, low osmotic fragility

questions.text: Which of the following is true about red blood cells in Sickle cell anemia: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) High mechanical fragility, low osmotic fragility

 

In sickle cell anemia, red blood cells (RBCs) have abnormal hemoglobin (HbS) that causes the cells to sickle under low oxygen conditions. These sickled cells are more prone to mechanical damage as they pass through the microcirculation, leading to increased mechanical fragility. However, their osmotic fragility is lower compared to normal RBCs because the sickling and subsequent damage to the cell membrane makes them less prone to osmotic lysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sickle cells exhibit high mechanical fragility due to their abnormal shape and membrane characteristics under stress but display low osmotic fragility because they are less prone to rupture in varying osmotic conditions compared to normal red blood cells.

choices.text: 2 and 4 are correct
1, 3 and 5 are correct
1, 4 and 5 are correct
2, 4 and 5 are correct

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are correct regarding mechanisms of depolarization, Repolarization, and hyperpolarization in a skeletal muscle action potential?(INICET May 2020)

 

  1. Depolarization due to influx of Na+ through voltage-gated channels
  2. Depolarization due to influx of Na+ through ligand-gated channels
  3. Repolarization due to efflux of K+ through a voltage-gated channel
  4. Repolarization due to efflux of K+ through a ligand-gated channel
  5. Hyperpolarization due to efflux of K+
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 3 and 5 are correct

 

Action potential in skeletal muscle:

 

During the onset of depolarization, voltage gated sodium channels open and there is slow influx of Na+. When depolarization reaches 7 to 10 mV, the voltage gated Na+ channels start opening at a faster rate. It is called Na+ channel activation. When the firing level is reached, the influx of Na+ is very great and it leads to overshoot.

 

But the Na+ transport is short lived. It is because of rapid inactivation of Na+ channels. Thus, the Na+ channels open and close quickly. At the same time, the K+ channels start opening. This leads to efflux of K+ out of the cell, causing repolarization.

 

Unlike the Na+ channels, the K+ channels remain open for longer duration. These channels remain opened for few more milliseconds after completion of repolarization. It causes efflux of a greater number of K+ producing more negativity inside. It is the cause for hyperpolarization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2 and 4 are correct: Incorrect. Depolarization in skeletal muscle is due to the influx of Na+ through voltage-gated channels, not ligand-gated channels. Repolarization is due to the efflux of K+ through voltage-gated channels, not ligand-gated channels.

 

Option C. 1, 4 and 5 are correct: Incorrect. Repolarization is due to the efflux of K+ through voltage-gated channels, not ligand-gated channels.

 

Option D. 2, 4 and 5 are correct: Incorrect. Depolarization in skeletal muscle is due to the influx of Na+ through voltage-gated channels, not ligand-gated channels, and repolarization is due to the efflux of K+ through voltage-gated channels, not ligand-gated channels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In skeletal muscle action potential, depolarization occurs due to the influx of Na+ through voltage-gated channels, repolarization occurs due to the efflux of K+ through voltage-gated channels, and hyperpolarization is caused by the prolonged efflux of K+.

questions.text: A 2-day-old full-term neonate is brought to the emergency department with repeated episodes of seizures since birth. The infant's seizures are clonic and multifocal, occurring within the first few hours of life, and have been refractory to standard anticonvulsant therapy. The baby was born via spontaneous vaginal delivery with no complications, and the pregnancy was uneventful. A genetic mutation affecting enzyme function has been identified, impairing the breakdown of certain metabolites. Which vitamin deficiency is most likely contributing to these neonatal seizures?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine)


Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6) deficiency can lead to neonatal seizures that are often refractory to conventional anticonvulsant medications. This condition is particularly severe in infancy and the newborn phase due to its critical role in neurotransmitter synthesis and brain metabolism. The seizures are typically clonic and multifocal, starting within the first few hours of life. The condition is linked to a mutation in the ALDH7A1 gene, which affects the breakdown of I-alpha-aminoadipic semialdehyde, an important process disrupted in pyridoxine deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B1 (Thiamine): Thiamine deficiency is associated with conditions like Wernicke’s encephalopathy and beriberi but is not typically linked to neonatal seizures.

 

Option C. Vitamin B12 (Cobalamin): Cobalamin deficiency usually presents with hematologic abnormalities and neurological symptoms later in infancy, not specifically with neonatal seizures.

 

Option D. Vitamin D: Vitamin D deficiency can lead to rickets and hypocalcemia but is not directly associated with neonatal seizures.

 

Educational Objective:


Pyridoxine deficiency can cause refractory neonatal seizures, often manifesting within hours of birth. It is caused by an ALDH7A1 gene mutation that impairs enzymatic breakdown processes essential for brain function. Early recognition and supplementation of Vitamin B6 are critical in managing this condition.

questions.text: Proteoglycan present in glomerular basement membrane?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Heparan Sulfate

 

Heparan sulfate is a major component of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM). It plays a crucial role in the molecular organization and function of the GBM. Heparan sulfate proteoglycans help maintain the integrity and selective permeability of the glomerular filtration barrier in the kidney, preventing the passage of large molecules like proteins into the urine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Keratan sulfate: Keratan sulfate is not typically found in the glomerular basement membrane. It is a component of other connective tissues and structures in the body.

 

Option C. Hyaluronic acid: Hyaluronic acid is a glycosaminoglycan (GAG) but is not a proteoglycan. It is found in various tissues and synovial fluid in joints but is not a major component of the glomerular basement membrane.

 

Option D. Dermatan sulfate: Dermatan sulfate is another glycosaminoglycan (GAG) but is not a proteoglycan commonly associated with the glomerular basement membrane. It is found in various connective tissues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GAGs (Location and Function)

 

 

 Ref- Harper 31st ed pg – 602

questions.text: Which of the following is an adverse effect with the long-term use of intermittent teriparatide for treatment of osteoporosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteosarcoma

 

Osteosarcoma is a rare but serious potential adverse effect associated with the long-term use of teriparatide. This risk was identified in animal studies where high doses of teriparatide caused osteosarcoma in rats. Although this effect has not been conclusively demonstrated in humans, the potential risk has led to caution in prescribing teriparatide for long durations, usually limited to a maximum of 2 years of use.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteonecrosis of the jaw bone: Osteonecrosis of the jaw is more commonly associated with bisphosphonates and denosumab, not with teriparatide. Teriparatide, being a parathyroid hormone analog, does not typically cause this condition.

 

Option C. Subtrochanteric fracture: Subtrochanteric fractures are more commonly associated with long-term use of bisphosphonates rather than teriparatide. Teriparatide, by stimulating new bone formation, is less likely to cause these types of fractures.

 

Option D. Loss of bone mass: Teriparatide is used to increase bone mass and strength by stimulating bone formation. Loss of bone mass is not a recognized adverse effect of teriparatide; rather, the medication is prescribed to counteract this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, the most significant potential adverse effect associated with the long-term use of teriparatide is the development of osteosarcoma, albeit this risk is based primarily on animal studies. Therefore, clinicians are advised to limit the duration of teriparatide therapy and monitor patients closely.

choices.text: Aspirin & clopidogrel
Decompressive surgery
Mechanical thrombectomy

questions.text: A 53-year-old man was admitted with history of a cerebrovascular accident 2 days ago. The patient is drowsy with minimal response. CT findings is shown in the image below. What will be your next line of management? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decompressive surgery

 

The CT scan image shows significant edema and midline shift affecting more than 50% of the Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA) territory. This extensive edema, along with the patient's low Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score, indicates severe brain swelling and increased intracranial pressure (ICP). In such cases, medical management alone (like mannitol for reducing ICP) may not be sufficient.

 

Guidelines for urgent decompression:

 

  • NIH Stroke scale > 15
  • Time < 48 hours
  • Age 18-60yrs
  • Territory infarct > 145cm3 or > 50% MCA territory
  • Informed consent that surgery improves survival but the patient may have significant disability.

 

Medical management of brain edema and increased intracranial pressure (ICP) may not be successful when significant swelling occurs in the cerebral or cerebellar hemisphere.

 

Therefore, a decompressive craniectomy should be considered to relieve the mass effect of the swollen cerebral or cerebellar hemisphere on the thalamus, brainstem and network projections to the cortex, which is manifested predominantly by decreased levels of arousal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspirin & clopidogrel: Incorrect as these medications are used for preventing further thrombotic events but are not suitable in the acute management of severe edema and brain shift.

 

Option B. Mannitol: Incorrect for sole use in this severe case, as it might not adequately control the mass effect and high ICP shown.

 

Option D. Mechanical thrombectomy: Incorrect because the primary issue in the CT image is the significant brain swelling and herniation risk, not an occlusion that can be resolved by thrombectomy at this stage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cases of significant cerebral edema with midline shift, as seen on CT in acute stroke settings, decompressive surgery is often necessary to prevent fatal outcomes and manage increased intracranial pressure effectively.

questions.text: When a codon is changed to stop codon, then it is: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Non-sense mutation

 

Amino acid codon is replaced by a stop codon causing premature termination of translation and truncated protein

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stop Codons mutation: There are specific codons known as "stop codons" that signal the termination of protein synthesis. These stop codons include UAA, UAG, and UGA. When a ribosome encounters a stop codon, it releases the newly synthesized protein, and protein synthesis comes to an end.

 

Option C. Mis-sense mutation: Codon for one amino acid is replaced by another amino acid codon causing change in protein properties.

 

Option D. Silent mutation: Codon is changed but amino acid is not changed due to codon degeneracy, so no effect on resulting protein.    

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 396

choices.text: Release of reactive oxygen species and free radicles
Suppression of angiogenesis
Inhibition of IL2, IL4, IL5

questions.text: Which of these options is not a mechanism contributing to thalidomide's teratogenic effects? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Inhibition of IL2, IL4, IL5

 

The teratogenic effects of thalidomide arise from a combination of factors such as oxidative stress, inhibition of blood vessel formation (anti-angiogenesis), and its interaction with a specific protein known as cereblon. This protein, CRBN, plays a significant role in the formation of cerebral tissues. Notably, its presence in various brain regions, including the hippocampus, is linked to functions like memory and learning processes.

 

Other Options:

 

Thalidomide's teratogenic effects are caused by several mechanisms, which include:

 

Option A. Release of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and free radicals: Thalidomide induces oxidative stress, leading to cellular damage during development, which is one of the key factors in its teratogenicity. ROS and free radicals cause damage to cellular components, leading to malformations.

 

Option B. Suppression of angiogenesis: Thalidomide inhibits the formation of new blood vessels, a critical process during embryogenesis. This suppression leads to improper development of limbs and organs, contributing significantly to the teratogenic effects seen in affected fetuses.

 

Option C. Cereblon binding: Thalidomide’s interaction with cereblon (CRBN), a protein crucial for limb and organ development, is another major mechanism of its teratogenicity. The binding of thalidomide to CRBN disrupts its normal function, leading to developmental abnormalities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thalidomide’s teratogenicity is primarily due to oxidative stress, inhibition of angiogenesis, and binding to cereblon, rather than the inhibition of interleukins IL2, IL4, and IL5.

choices.text: HBsAg, IgM anti-HBc, Anti-HCV, Anti HEV
HBsAg, IgM anti-HBc, Anti-HDV, Anti-HEV, Anti-HCV

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male chronic smoker presents to the AIIMS OPD with fever, fatigue, yellow-colored urine, and RUQ pain. For the past few days, he has developed an aversion to eating food. On examination icterus was present. What investigations would you advise to rule out acute viral hepatitis? (AIIMS MAY 2018)


Liver function test results are given below:

 

  • Total Bilirubin 18.5
  • Direct Bilirubin 10.5   
  • SGOT/AST 723
  • SGPT/ALT 812
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anti-HAV, HBsAg, IgM anti-HBc, Anti-HCV

 

Above history is suggestive of acute viral hepatitis with ALT>AST and elevated >10X times. With resolution of symptoms jaundice gradually increases and spontaneously improves.

 

Common causes of AST, ALT > 10X are Viral Hepatitis (B, A, C-rare, E-In pregnancy/Post-transplant), Toxins, Shock liver, Fulminant Wilsons.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-HEV testing routinely not employed

 

Option C. Hepatitis D usually causes severe disease when B+D coinfection occurs.

 

Option D. HbsAg is first test of hep B infection W/IgM HbC suggest FLARE, window period, acute infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of suspected acute viral hepatitis with significant liver enzyme elevation and icterus, it's essential to conduct a thorough serological evaluation to determine the specific type of hepatitis virus involved. This allows for targeted management and appropriate precautions to prevent transmission.

 

Reference: Harrison/gastroenterology/Viral Hepatitis/Chap 339

questions.text: The pretracheal layer of deep cervical fascia encloses all of the following except?(INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sternocleidomastoid

 

All the above structures are enclosed by the pretracheal layer of deep cervical fascia except sternocleidomastoid. It is enclosed by the investing layer of deep cervical fascia.

 

The deep cervical fascia of the neck is organized into the following layers:

 

  • The investing layer - surrounds all structures in the neck
  • The prevertebral layer - surrounds the vertebral column and the deep muscles associated with the back.
  • The pretracheal layer - encloses the viscera of the neck
  • The carotid sheath - receives a contribution from the other three fascial layers

 

The strap muscles of the neck, including the sternohyoid, omohyoid, sternothyroid, and thyrohyoid, are covered by the pretracheal fascia. To encapsulate the thyroid gland, it divides. The recurrent laryngeal nerve, which is located in the groove between the trachea and the oesophagus, is likewise surrounded by this tissue.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Esophagus: The esophagus is indeed enclosed by the pretracheal fascia in its cervical portion. The fascia extends posteriorly from the trachea to envelop the esophagus, giving some form of fascial support to this structure as it descends through the neck.

 

Option C. Sternohyoid: The sternohyoid muscle is one of the infrahyoid muscles and lies superficially in the anterior part of the neck. It is indeed enclosed by the pretracheal layer of the deep cervical fascia. This layer of fascia extends inferiorly from the hyoid bone to the thorax and surrounds the thyroid gland, trachea, and infrahyoid muscles, including the sternohyoid.

 

Option D. Thyroid gland: The thyroid gland is an endocrine gland situated anteriorly in the midline and the side of the neck, straddling the trachea. The pretracheal fascia contributes to the formation of the capsule of the thyroid gland, thus enclosing it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sternocleidomastoid muscle (SCM) is not enclosed by the pretracheal fascia. Instead, the SCM is associated with the superficial layer of the deep cervical fascia (also known as the investing layer). This layer of the fascia envelops both the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles, acting as an investing layer for these superficial neck muscles.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis seen in the image below?  NEET PG 2019
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Candidal intertrigo

 

The condition shown in the image is Candidal intertrigo.

 

Various types of candidiasis:

 

  1. Candidal intertrigo:
    • Manifests with erythematous, non-scaly moist patches of opposing skin surfaces, with a little moist exudation starting deep in a fold.
    • When the web spaces of the toes or fingers are affected, marked maceration with a thick, white, horny layer is usually prominent.
    • Tiny, superficial, white pustular satellite lesions can be seen at the margins of the intertriginous patch.
  2. Candidal paronychia: Swelling of nail fold
  3. Candidal balanoposthitis: Seen in patients with uncontrolled diabetes mellitus, associated with swelling of prepuce.
  4. Perlèche/ Angular stomatitis: Soreness and cracking at the angles of the mouth are seen in Perlèche. It is considered as an intertrigo where candida is the most common organism implicated.

 

 

Investigations:

 

  • KOH mount → Pseudo hyphae

 

Treatment:

 

  • Topical: Antifungal agents such as nystatin, ketoconazole, and clotrimazole are routinely used.
  • Oral: Fluconazole

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candidal paronychia

  • This refers to an infection of the nail fold, leading to a painful and red swelling around the nail.
  • It can be due to bacterial or candidal infection.

 

Option C. Diabetic foot ulcer

  • This is an open sore or wound commonly located on the bottom of the foot in people with diabetes.
  • Factors leading to diabetic foot ulcers include neuropathy, peripheral arterial disease, foot deformities, and trauma.
  • The skin around the ulcer may be calloused or discolored but not typically macerated.

 

Option D. Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS)

  • This is a serious skin disorder caused by the exotoxins of Staphylococcus aureus.
  • It primarily affects infants and young children.
  • It is characterized by blistering and the appearance that the top layer of skin is scalded or burned.
  • SSSS affects larger areas of the body and often starts with facial erythema, widespread redness, and blisters, which then rupture, leaving raw areas. Maceration of toe web spaces would not be a primary symptom.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Candidal intertrigo can be identified by the classic presentation of erythema, maceration, and possible white exudate in skin folds, such as the web spaces between fingers, distinguishing it from conditions that affect the nail folds, feet, or involve widespread skin desquamation.

 

Reference:  Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition Chapter 32, Page nos 32.61-32.63

questions.text: Match the following? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A-4, B-1, C-2, D-3

 

  • Malaria (A-4, Giemsa stain): Giemsa's solution is a mixture of methylene blue, eosin, and Azure B. It is used to stain blood smears for the identification of malarial parasites. Giemsa's stain is regarded as the world's standard diagnostic technique for malaria's plasmodium, and it is also the basic stain for classifying lymphomas in the Kiel classification.
  • Tuberculosis (B-1, ZN stain): The Ziehl-Neelsen method uses a carbol fuchsin stain, acid alcohol decolorizer, and methylene blue counterstain. Acid-fast organisms, such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis, stain red, while the background of debris stains blue. The ZN stain confirms the acid-fast property of mycobacteria.
  • Leprosy (C-2, Fite Faraco stain): Fite-Faraco stain is the routinely used method to demonstrate Mycobacterium leprae in tissue sections. It is more sensitive than the ZN method in the detection of Mycobacterium leprae in tissue sections. The leprosy bacillus is much less acid and alcohol fast than the tubercle bacillus, therefore alcohol is removed from the hydrating and dehydrating steps and 10% sulphuric acid is used as a decolorizer in place of acid/alcohol solution.

 

Mycobacterial cell walls contain a waxy substance composed of mycolic acids. These are ß-hydroxy carboxylic acids with chain lengths of up to 90 carbon atoms. The property of acid fastness is related to the carbon chain length of the mycolic acid found in any particular species.

 

  • Actinomycosis (D-3, Gram stain): Actinomyces species are gram-positive bacteria, and the Gram stain is used to visualize them. Actinomyces appear as filamentous, branching, gram-positive rods when stained with the Gram stain. Gram stain is more sensitive for the diagnosis of actinomycosis than culture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Each infectious disease has a specific staining technique for identification: Malaria (Giemsa stain), Tuberculosis (ZN stain), Leprosy (Fite Faraco stain), and Actinomycosis (Gram stain).

choices.text: Failure of migration of neural crest cells

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the pathogenesis of Hirschsprung disease? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Failure of migration of neural crest cells

 

Hirschsprung disease is caused by the failure of neural crest cells to migrate to the bowel wall.

 

Hirschsprung disease, also known as congenital aganglionic megacolon, occurs when the normal migration of neural crest cells from the cecum to the rectum is interrupted or the ganglion cells die prematurely. This results in a distal intestinal segment with neither the Meissner submucosal nor the Auerbach myenteric plexus ("aganglionosis"). Coordinated peristaltic contractions are absent, and functional obstruction occurs, resulting in proximal dilation.

 

The absence of ganglion cells in the distal bowel leads to an inability to coordinate peristaltic contractions, resulting in functional obstruction and proximal bowel dilation. This can lead to symptoms such as abdominal distension, constipation, and failure to pass meconium shortly after birth.

 

The diagnosis of Hirschsprung disease is made based on a combination of clinical presentation, radiographic findings, and histologic examination of rectal biopsy specimens. Treatment typically involves surgical resection of the aganglionic segment of the bowel, followed by re-anastomosis or creation of a colostomy.

 

Complications of Hirschsprung disease include enterocolitis, fecal impaction, and even sepsis, so early diagnosis and prompt treatment are important to prevent these complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Loss of ganglion cells: While the result of the disease is a bowel segment lacking ganglion cells, the primary cause is the failure of migration of neural crest cells rather than a secondary loss of ganglion cells.

 

Option C. Visceral myopathy: Visceral myopathy involves primary muscle pathology of the bowel, which is not the cause of Hirschsprung disease.

 

Option D. Obstruction by inflammatory stricture: Inflammatory strictures are not related to the pathogenesis of Hirschsprung disease, which is due to congenital aganglionosis rather than inflammation or stricture formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hirschsprung disease is primarily caused by the failure of neural crest cells to migrate to the bowel wall during embryonic development, resulting in aganglionosis in the distal bowel and leading to functional obstruction and proximal bowel dilation.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presented with cola colored urine and had a history of skin infection few days back. His creatinine value was initially 2.5 mg/dl but even after 3 weeks of treatment it increased to 4.5 mg/dl. Which of the following is a likely kidney biopsy finding on electron microscopy? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subepithelial deposits

 

A child with skin infection followed by passage of cola colored urine is suggestive of post streptococcal glomerulonephritis. The worsening of creatinine from 2.5mg/dl to 4.5 mg/dl is suggestive of worsen of his condition in a short span of time. This prompts a diagnosis of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN).

 

Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis (RPGN):

 

  • Pathology: RPGN is characterized by the presence of crescents in the glomeruli, which are formed by the proliferation of parietal epithelial cells and infiltration of monocytes and macrophages.
  • Clinical Features: Rapid deterioration of renal function, often following an infection such as streptococcal throat or skin infection.
  • Crescents can be seen on light microscopy in RPGN (especially crescentic PSGN).
  • But electron microscopy (EM) will still show subepithelial deposits, which is diagnostic of PSGN.
  • So, even though the clinical course is RPGN, the question asked what you see on EM - hence the correct answer is Subepithelial deposits
  • Type I: Anti-GBM disease (Goodpasture syndrome)
  • Type II: Immune complex-mediated (e.g., PSGN, lupus nephritis)
  • Type III: Pauci-immune (e.g., Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis, also known as Wegener’s)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subendothelial deposits: Seen in conditions like lupus nephritis and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, not typical for RPGN following PSGN.

 

Option C. Crescents in glomeruli: Suggest RPGN, but the specific hallmark of PSGN is subepithelial humps (crescents may appear if it evolves into RPGN, but not diagnostic)

 

Option D. Mesangial deposits: Commonly seen in IgA nephropathy and other mesangioproliferative glomerulonephritis, not specific for RPGN.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of crescents in the glomeruli on kidney biopsy is characteristic of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN), especially in a patient with worsening renal function following an episode of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. However, crescents can be seen on light microscopy.

choices.text: Category A - Easily transmitted and are associated with high mortality rates
Category D - Re-emerging diseases that are high priority agents
Category C - Emerging diseases that are easy to disseminate and are associated with high mortality rates
Category B - Slow to disseminate and are associated with low mortality rates

questions.text: According to the CDC classification of bioterrorism agents, which one of the following statements is untrue? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Category D - Re-emerging diseases that are high priority agents

 

  • As per the CDC, bioterrorism agents are categorized solely into three groups, namely Category A, B, and C, with no classification for a Category D.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Type II error is small and we can accept the findings of the study
The probability of false negative conclusion that operation A is better than B is 4%
The power of the study to detect the difference between operation A and B is 96%
The probability of a false positive conclusion that operation A is better than B is 4%

questions.text: During a journal club discussion on a randomized controlled trial comparing two surgical techniques for direct inguinal hernia, the reported p-value is 0.04. What is the most accurate interpretation of this p-value? [AIIMS MAY 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) The probability of a false positive conclusion that operation A is better than B is 4%

 

  • With a calculated p-value of 0.04, we can deduce that there is a 4% chance of arriving at a false positive conclusion, suggesting that operation A is superior to operation B.
  • In this context, the p-value of 0.04 attains statistical significance by conventional standards.
  • Consequently, we have grounds to reject the null hypothesis and accept the alternative hypothesis, indicating that operation A outperforms operation B.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A p-value of 0.04 suggests that there is a statistically significant difference, at the 5% significance level, between the surgical techniques being compared, assuming the risk of a false positive conclusion is acceptable at 4%.

questions.text: Which one of the following drugs inhibits neutrophil recruitment? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Colchicine

 

Colchicine is primarily used to treat gout and familial Mediterranean fever. One of its mechanisms of action is the inhibition of neutrophil migration into inflamed tissues, thereby reducing inflammation. It disrupts the microtubules inside cells, including neutrophils, affecting their mobility and reducing their recruitment to sites of inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Montelukast: Montelukast is a leukotriene receptor antagonist used mainly for asthma and allergic rhinitis. While it can reduce inflammation, its primary action is not on neutrophil recruitment.

 

Option B. Sodium Cromolyn: Sodium cromolyn is a mast cell stabilizer used to treat conditions like asthma and allergic rhinitis. It prevents the release of histamine and other inflammatory mediators from mast cells but doesn't directly inhibit neutrophil recruitment.

 

Option D. Febuxostat: Febuxostat is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor used for the treatment of chronic gout. It reduces uric acid production but doesn't specifically inhibit neutrophil recruitment.

 

Therefore, Colchicine is the drug that inhibits neutrophil recruitment, making option C the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Colchicine is the drug that inhibits neutrophil recruitment by disrupting microtubules, thus affecting neutrophil mobility and reducing inflammation. This mechanism makes it effective in treating conditions like gout and familial Mediterranean fever.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with painless, massive lower gastrointestinal bleeding. He is diagnosed with Meckel's diverticulum, and surgical treatment is planned. Which of the following is the most commonly encountered ectopic tissue in Meckel's diverticulum? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gastric and pancreatic

 

Meckel's diverticulum is a congenital anomaly caused by a failure of normal regression of the vitelline duct during gestation. The rule of 2s mnemonic for Meckel's diverticulum includes 2 types of heterotopic mucosa (gastric and pancreatic), located within 2 feet of the ileocecal valve, approximately 2 inches in length, and with a 2% incidence.

 

Meckel's diverticulum can present with painless, massive lower gastrointestinal bleeding, and it can be a lead point for ileoileal or ileocolic intussusception. Diagnosis is confirmed with a 99mTc-pertechnetate isotope scan to detect gastric mucosa and pancreatic tissue.

 

Surgical treatment is the definitive therapy for Meckel's diverticulum, and V-shaped diverticulectomy with transverse closure of the ileum is commonly performed.

choices.text: Oral rehydration therapy, zinc supplements, and breastfeeding
Continue usual feeding and give home fluids
Immediate referral to the hospital with intravenous fluids

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother due to a history of loose stool. The mother denies any fever or blood in the stools but reports that the child is irritable and eagerly drinks water when offered. On examination, the child’s eyes are sunken, and the skin pinch test reveals slow retraction within two seconds. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Oral rehydration therapy, zinc supplements, and breastfeeding

 

The clinical signs indicate that the child has some dehydration. This classification is based on the presence of restlessness and irritability, sunken eyes, eagerness to drink water, and a sluggish skin retraction within two seconds on the skin pinch test. According to the WHO Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illnesses (IMNCI) guidelines, the appropriate management for some dehydration is classified under Plan B, which includes:

 

  • Oral Rehydration Therapy (ORT): To replace lost fluids and electrolytes.
  • Zinc Supplements: To reduce the duration and severity of diarrhea.
  • Sustained Breastfeeding: To continue providing nutrition and hydration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intravenous fluids and antibiotics: This is not appropriate as the child shows signs of some dehydration, not severe dehydration or infection requiring antibiotics.

 

Option C. Continue usual feeding and give home fluids: This is suitable for no dehydration cases, not some dehydration.

 

Option D. Immediate referral to the hospital with intravenous fluids: This is recommended for severe dehydration, which is not indicated in this child.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Children with some dehydration should be managed with oral rehydration therapy, zinc supplementation, and continued breastfeeding according to IMNCI guidelines to prevent progression to severe dehydration and aid in recovery.
