questions.text: Which of the following does not favor euchromatin formation due to changes occurring at Cytosine residues at Cp islands in DNA?(AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Methylation 

 

Euchromatin is a form of chromatin that is loosely packed and transcriptionally active, allowing for the expression of genes. The formation and maintenance of euchromatin are influenced by various post-translational modifications of DNA and histones.

 

Methylation of Cytosine Residues at CpG Islands:

 

  • CpG Islands: These are regions of DNA with a high frequency of CpG dinucleotides, often found near gene promoters and regulatory regions.
  • Methylation: The addition of methyl groups to cytosine residues in CpG islands is associated with gene silencing and the formation of heterochromatin (inactive, condensed chromatin). This methylation process hinders the binding of transcription factors and other regulatory proteins, leading to a more compact chromatin structure and reduced gene expression.
  • Impact on Euchromatin: Methylation of cytosine residues is a key epigenetic modification that does not favor euchromatin formation because it inactivates the DNA, leading to a transcriptionally inactive state.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Phosphorylation: Phosphorylation of histones can promote chromatin remodeling and gene expression, thus favoring euchromatin formation.

 

Option C. Alkylation: Alkylation typically refers to the addition of alkyl groups to DNA or histones, which can have varying effects. However, it does not specifically inhibit euchromatin formation in the way that methylation does.

 

Option D. Sumoylation: Sumoylation involves the addition of small ubiquitin-like modifier (SUMO) proteins to histones or other proteins. This modification generally influences protein stability and function, but it does not directly interfere with euchromatin formation like methylation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methylation of cytosine residues at CpG islands is associated with gene silencing and the formation of transcriptionally inactive heterochromatin, thus not favoring euchromatin formation.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient with a history of abdominal pain and fever for the past three days presents to the hospital. The physician orders a chest X-ray in the erect position which shows abnormal findings. Based on these findings, the most likely diagnosis will be determined? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hollow viscus perforation

 

  • Air under the diaphragm is seen in the given erect radiograph, which is a characteristic finding of hollow viscus perforation.
  •  Perforation of a viscus can lead to peritonitis, which is inflammation of the peritoneum due to the spillage of fluids into the peritoneal cavity or secondary bacterial infection.
  • Clinical features of hollow viscus perforation include abdominal pain, distension, nausea, vomiting, tachycardia, tenderness, rebound tenderness, and guarding on palpation.
  •  Fever may also be present, and septic shock can occur in later stages.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastric volvulus: Gastric volvulus refers to the twisting of the stomach on its axis. It can result in obstruction and ischemia. Symptoms include severe epigastric pain, vomiting, and difficulty in passing a nasogastric tube. On imaging, the stomach may be abnormally positioned, often with a characteristic appearance described as an "inverted stomach" or "upside-down stomach." While it can cause serious complications, air under the diaphragm on an erect chest radiograph is not typically associated with gastric volvulus.

 

Option C. Liver abscess: A liver abscess is typically caused by bacterial or amoebic infection. Symptoms include fever, abdominal pain, jaundice, and weight loss. An erect chest radiograph isn't the primary modality to diagnose a liver abscess. Instead, an ultrasound or CT scan of the abdomen would be more appropriate to visualize an abscess within the liver.

 

Option D. Empyema thoracis: Empyema refers to the accumulation of pus in the pleural cavity (space between the lung and the chest wall). It's usually a complication of pneumonia or thoracic surgery. Symptoms include fever, cough, chest pain, and breathlessness. On a chest radiograph, the empyema may appear as a fluid level or a white opacity, depending on its stage and the amount of fluid. An erect chest X-ray may be used to diagnose empyema, but it would not typically show free air under the diaphragm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Air under the diaphragm seen on an erect chest radiograph is a hallmark finding of a hollow viscus perforation, which is a surgical emergency requiring immediate attention to prevent peritonitis and other severe complications.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child was brought to OPD with proptosis of left eye. On investigation, it was found to be a Desmin positive tumour. What can be the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma

 

Given clinical scenario and tumor showing Desmin positive, points to a diagnosis of Embryonal Rhabdomyosarcoma.

 

Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma presents as a soft gray infiltrative mass. The tumor cells mimic skeletal muscle at various stages of differentiation and consist of sheets of both primitive round and spindled cells. Rhabdomyoblasts with straplike cytoplasm and visible cross-striations may be present.

 

Sarcoma botryoides is a variant of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma that develops in the walls of hollow viscera such as the urinary bladder and vagina.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ewing's sarcoma: Ewing's sarcoma is typically positive for CD99 and is more commonly found in bone or soft tissue, not usually associated with Desmin positivity.

 

Option C. Leukemia: Leukemia cells are positive for CD45 (leukocyte common antigen) and are not associated with Desmin positivity or presenting as a soft tissue mass with proptosis.

 

Option D. Retinoblastoma: Retinoblastoma is a malignant tumor of the retina, typically presenting with leukocoria (white pupillary reflex) and is associated with RB1 gene mutations. It is not associated with Desmin positivity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma, a common pediatric soft tissue sarcoma, is typically Desmin-positive and can present with proptosis, particularly when it arises in the orbit.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 2435-2437

questions.text: Which of the following hormones is exclusively secreted by adrenal gland but not by the ovaries of females? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) DHEA-S

 

DHEAS is exclusively secreted from the adrenals but not by ovaries because ovaries lack the enzyme dehydroepiandrosterone-sulphotransferase needed to form DHEAS.

 

Adrenal hormones

 

  1. Zona glomerulosa – Aldosterone
  2. Zona fasciculata – glucocorticoids cortisol, corticosterone, as well as small amounts of adrenal androgens and estrogens
  3. The zona reticularis – adrenal androgens dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA. and androstenedione, as well as small amounts of estrogens and some glucocorticoids

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Progesterone: Incorrect. Progesterone is secreted by both the adrenal glands and the ovaries.

 

Option B. DHEA: Incorrect. DHEA is secreted by both the adrenal glands and the ovaries.

 

Option C. Estrogen: Incorrect. Estrogen is produced by both the ovaries and the adrenal glands.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DHEA-S (dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate) is exclusively secreted by the adrenal glands and not by the ovaries because the ovaries lack the enzyme necessary to produce DHEA-S.

questions.text:
Which of the following is True regarding drugs used for viral infections?

 

  1. Treatment of HCV with ribavirin is considered better than sofosbuvir
  2. Ombitasvir is inhibitor of proteins synthesis
  3. Imiquimod is used for Condyloma acuminata
  4. Simprevir inhibits protease of hepatitis C
  5. Oseltamivir is used for swine flu
questions.solution:
Ans. A. C, D and E

 

C. Imiquimod is used for Condyloma acuminata: This statement is true. Imiquimod is an immunomodulator used for the treatment of various viral warts, including condyloma acuminata (genital warts).

 

D. Simprevir inhibits protease of hepatitis C: This statement is true. Simprevir is a protease inhibitor used in the treatment of HCV, which works by inhibiting the NS3/4A protease enzyme necessary for viral replication.

 

E. Oseltamivir is used for swine flu: This statement is true. Oseltamivir is an antiviral medication effective against influenza A (including H5N1 and H1N1, commonly known as swine flu) and influenza B.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Treatment of HCV with ribavirin is considered better than sofosbuvir: This statement is false. Ribavirin, when used for the treatment of Hepatitis C Virus (HCV), must be combined with injectable interferons, which have significant adverse effects. Sofosbuvir, a newer oral drug that inhibits the NS5B RNA polymerase, is preferred over ribavirin due to its better efficacy and fewer side effects.

 

Option B. Ombitasvir is an inhibitor of protein synthesis: This statement is false. Ombitasvir is an NS5A inhibitor, meaning it acts by inhibiting viral RNA replication and assembly of the hepatitis C virus (HCV), not protein synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sofosbuvir is preferred over ribavirin for HCV treatment due to better efficacy, ombitasvir is an NS5A inhibitor, imiquimod is used for condyloma acuminata, simprevir inhibits HCV protease, and oseltamivir is used for swine flu.

 

 

Reference: KDT 8th/. 853,856,858

choices.text: Facilitates conversion of bilirubin to a conjugated form
Changes bilirubin into a soluble isomer that is excreted via the kidneys
Modifies intestinal flora to aid in bilirubin elimination

questions.text: A 3-day-old full-term neonate is brought to the emergency department due to yellow discoloration of the skin noticed since the second day of life. The infant is otherwise healthy, feeding well, and shows no signs of distress. Physical examination confirms jaundice involving the face and trunk. Laboratory studies reveal elevated total bilirubin levels with a predominance of indirect (unconjugated) bilirubin. The medical team initiates phototherapy to manage the condition and prevent complications. What is the primary effect of phototherapy on bilirubin?
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) Changes bilirubin into a soluble isomer that is excreted via the kidneys


Phototherapy treats neonatal jaundice by exposing bilirubin to visible light, which triggers several changes. The main mechanism is the conversion of bilirubin into lumirubin through irreversible structural isomerization, making it water-soluble and allowing for renal excretion without the need for liver conjugation.

 

 

Other mechanisms include:

 

  • Reversible Photo-Isomerization: This process converts unconjugated bilirubin into a different isomer that can be excreted in bile without conjugation.
  • Photo-Oxidation: A minor pathway where bilirubin undergoes slight oxidative changes, enhancing its breakdown and excretion.
  • Contraindication: Phototherapy is contraindicated in conditions such as porphyria due to the risk of severe skin reactions, including photosensitivity and blistering.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Facilitates conversion of bilirubin to a conjugated form: Incorrect, as phototherapy does not involve conjugation; this is a liver function independent of light exposure.

 

Option C. Enhances hepatic processing of bilirubin: Incorrect, as phototherapy does not affect the liver’s ability to process bilirubin; it alters the bilirubin outside the liver.

 

Option D. Modifies intestinal flora to aid in bilirubin elimination: Incorrect because phototherapy does not alter gut flora; its primary role is changing bilirubin’s structure to facilitate renal excretion.

 

Educational Objective:


Phototherapy reduces bilirubin levels in neonatal jaundice by converting unconjugated bilirubin into lumirubin, a water-soluble form that can be excreted by the kidneys. This process helps prevent bilirubin toxicity and complications such as kernicterus.

choices.text: Anti CTLA 4 Ab is a new modality in the treatment of advanced cancers
Mutation of tumor suppressor genes decreases antigen toxicity
PD1/ PDL1 activation leading to tumor suppression
Binding of CD28 leads to immune tolerance

questions.text: Identify the correct statement regarding immune surveillance? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anti CTLA 4 Ab is a new modality in the treatment of advanced cancers

 

CTLA4 is a negative regulator of T-cell responses. recognition of tumor cells may lead to engagement of the T-cell inhibitory receptor, CTLA4, or activation of regulatory T cells that suppress immune responses. Antibodies that block the interaction of CTLA-4 with its ligands B7. 1 and B7. 2 can enhance immune responses, including anti-tumor immunity.

 

Ipilimumab, a fully humanized IgG1 monoclonal Anti CTLA-4 antibody, has shown a significant improvement in survival of advanced-stage melanoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mutation of tumor suppressor genes decreases antigen toxicity: This statement is incorrect because mutations in tumor suppressor genes (e.g., TP53) lead to the loss of cell cycle control and contribute to tumorigenesis, not decreased antigen toxicity.

 

Option C. PD1/PDL1 activation leading to tumor suppression: The PD-1/PD-L1 pathway is another immune checkpoint that, when activated, suppresses the immune response. In cancer, tumors often upregulate PD-L1 to evade immune destruction, so this pathway is involved in immune evasion, not suppression of tumors.

 

Option D. Binding of CD28 leads to immune tolerance: CD28 is a co-stimulatory molecule that, when bound to B7 on APCs, promotes T-cell activation rather than tolerance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-CTLA-4 antibodies like Ipilimumab are a new modality in the treatment of advanced cancers, enhancing the anti-tumor immune response by blocking inhibitory signals to T cells.

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 574

questions.text:
A drug was given IV at a rate of 1.6 mg/min. The clearance of the drug is 640 ml/min.

The half-life of the drug is 1.8 hour. Calculate the plasma concentration of the drug?(AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 0.002mg/ml

 

Plasma conc of a drug (C) = Amount of drug being eliminated/Clearance

 

When the amount of drug administered equals the amount of drug eliminated from the body, steady-state plasma concentration is reached.

 

The amount of drug being administered = 1.6 mg/min

 

Clearance = 640ml/min

 

Therefore,

 

Plasma concentration of the drug = 1.6 mg/min / 640 ml/min = 0.0025 mg/ml.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When given the rate of infusion and clearance, the steady-state plasma concentration of a drug can be calculated using the formula:

 

Plasma concentration (C)=Rate of infusion (R)/ Clearance (Cl)

questions.text: A 20-year-old girl presents with primary amenorrhea. On examination breasts were found to be poorly developed, vagina was present. Ultrasound revealed a normal uterus, but gonads weren't detected. Further evaluation done showed 46XY karyotype. The most probable diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Swyer's syndrome

 

The clinical scenario described is indicative of Swyer syndrome, which is characterized by a 46XY karyotype and gonadal dysgenesis.

 

Key points about Swyer syndrome:

 

  • Swyer syndrome, also known as 46XY gonadal dysgenesis, is a condition where individuals with an XY karyotype present phenotypically as females.
  • These patients have a normal uterus and vagina but lack functioning gonads, which are often termed "streak gonads."
  • Because of gonadal dysgenesis, these individuals do not secrete testosterone or Antimullerian Hormone (AMH), leading to the development of female genital organs and phenotype.
  • Clinical presentation includes primary amenorrhea, absence of secondary sexual characteristics, and female external genitalia despite a 46XY karyotype.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Androgen insensitivity syndrome: Also known as testicular feminization syndrome, individuals have a 46XY karyotype but are phenotypically female with well-developed breasts and absent axillary and pubic hair. The gonads are testes, and there is no uterus.

 

Option B. Turner syndrome: Turner syndrome is characterized by a 45XO karyotype. Patients typically present with short stature, shield chest, cubitus valgus, poorly developed secondary sexual characteristics, and streak ovaries.

 

Option C. True hermaphrodite: True hermaphrodites have both ovarian and testicular tissue present, which is not consistent with the clinical scenario described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Swyer syndrome (46XY gonadal dysgenesis) is a condition where individuals with a 46XY karyotype present phenotypically as females with primary amenorrhea, poorly developed secondary sexual characteristics, and a normal uterus but lack functioning gonads.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 33446, Williams textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg373

questions.text: Choose the correctly matched pairs regarding the drugs used in schizophrenia:(INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1,2,4

 

Schizophrenia is managed with antipsychotic drugs that act on various neurotransmitter systems. Understanding their mechanisms of action and effects is essential for appropriate treatment. Here's a detailed look at each pair:

 

1. D2 antagonism – Reduces positive symptoms:

  •  
  • True. Positive symptoms of schizophrenia, such as hallucinations and delusions, are primarily managed by blocking dopamine D2 receptors. Typical antipsychotics like haloperidol and chlorpromazine are potent D2 antagonists and effectively reduce these symptoms.

 

2. 5HT2A antagonism – Reduces negative symptoms:

  •  
  • True. Atypical antipsychotics (e.g., clozapine, olanzapine) act by blocking serotonin 5HT2A receptors. This action helps to improve both the positive and negative symptoms of schizophrenia, with a significant impact on negative symptoms like social withdrawal and apathy.

 

4. Muscarinic receptor antagonism – Reduces extrapyramidal symptoms:

  •  
  • True. Antagonism of muscarinic receptors can help reduce extrapyramidal side effects (EPS) caused by D2 antagonism. Drugs like benztropine, which are anticholinergics, are used to manage EPS by balancing the cholinergic and dopaminergic activities in the brain.

 

Other Options

 

3. 5HT1A agonism – Weight loss:

 

    • False. The 5HT1A receptor agonism is not directly associated with weight loss. In fact, weight gain is a common side effect of many atypical antipsychotics, which act on multiple serotonin and dopamine receptors. The statement should be regarding 5HT2C antagonism, which is associated with weight gain, not loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antipsychotic drugs manage schizophrenia by targeting various neurotransmitter systems. D2 antagonism helps reduce positive symptoms, while 5HT2A antagonism improves negative symptoms. Muscarinic receptor antagonism can help mitigate extrapyramidal side effects. Misconceptions about receptor effects, such as 5HT1A agonism causing weight loss, need to be corrected.

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of cirrhosis of the liver presents with abdominal distension and swelling of the lower limbs. The preferred diuretic for this patient would be?(INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Eplerenone

 

  • Eplerenone is a mineralocorticoid (Aldosterone) receptor antagonist and a potassium sparing diuretic. In a patient of cirrhosis, there is splanchnic vasodilation, due to which there is decreased effective arterial blood volume. This stimulates the RAAS axis and as a result, the levels of Aldosterone are increased. Aldosterone ultimately leads to increased absorption of Na+ and water from the late distal tubules and collecting ducts along with excretion of K+ and H+ into the lumen.
  • This increased sodium and water retention leads to the development of ascites and edema.
  • Eplerenone, like Spironolactone, blocks this action of Aldosterone and leads to natriuresis and diuresis, without causing loss of K+. Therefore, it is the preferred drug in this patient.
  • It is important to note that in clinical practice, a combination of a loop diuretic (like furosemide) and an aldosterone antagonist (like spironolactone or eplerenone) is typically used for managing ascites and peripheral edema in cirrhosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Triamterene: Triamterene is also a potassium-sparing diuretic, but it works by blocking sodium channels in the distal nephron. It is less effective than aldosterone antagonists like eplerenone in managing ascites related to cirrhosis.

 

Option C. Chlorthalidone: Chlorthalidone is a thiazide-like diuretic that inhibits sodium reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule. Thiazide diuretics are not as effective in the setting of cirrhosis with ascites and are not typically used for this purpose.

 

Option D. Acetazolamide: Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that acts on the proximal tubule. It is used primarily to treat metabolic alkalosis and glaucoma, and is not suitable for treating ascites and peripheral edema in cirrhosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eplerenone, as a mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist and potassium-sparing diuretic, is the preferred choice for managing ascites and peripheral edema in patients with cirrhosis due to its ability to counteract the effects of elevated aldosterone levels.

questions.text: A 28-year-old public health nurse is attending a seminar on primary prevention strategies. She needs to identify interventions that fall under specific protection, a subset of primary prevention. Which of the following interventions does NOT come under the primary level of prevention for specific protection? [AIIMS NOV 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Hand washing

 

  • Specific protection mode of disease prevention: Is a Primary level of disease prevention (applied when risk factors are present in environment but disease has not yet taken place).
  • Risk factors are already present but disease is prevented from occurring by using a specific modality. Ex - Vaccines & Vit A supplementation under NIS, chemoprophylaxis, IFA supplementation, contraception, ITN, etc
  • Handwashing fall within the category of primary prevention as a Health Promotion measure, not specific protection, as it is not a protective measures targeted at any particular disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Meningitis prophylaxis in exposed contacts/relatives: This is a form of specific protection, aimed at preventing the onset of meningitis in those exposed to the infection.

 

Option C. Vaccination: Vaccination is a classic example of specific protection, preventing the occurrence of specific diseases.

 

Option D. Adding iron to wheat flour: This is a specific protection measure to prevent iron deficiency anemia in the population by fortifying commonly consumed food products.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hand washing is a health promotion measure and does not fall under specific protection in primary prevention strategies.
  • Note - Chinese Medicine is the Pioneer in concept of ‘Specific protection by vaccine’

choices.text: FeSO4 + Vit C + Folate + Vit B12

questions.text: You work as a medical officer in a Primary Health Center (PHC). You are tasked with developing a strategy to address widespread anemia in the community. Considering the need for efficacy, safety, and ease of administration, which of the following options would you recommend for the prevention and treatment of anemia in this setting? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) FeSO4 + Vit C + Folate + Vit B12

 

  • Among the given options, FeSO4 + vitamin C + Folate + vitamin B12 is likely to be the best mass prophylaxis against anemia.
  • Vit C enhances the absorption of iron from the stomach by acting as a reducing substance.
  • Supplementing vitamin B12 can reduce incidence and prevalence of megaloblastic anemia as cost factor is not that significant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Iron (III) hydroxide polymaltose: It is not yet evident to be more efficacious than FeSO4

 

Option C. Ferrous fumarate: It is considered to be equally efficacious but vitamin C as an adjunct improves absorption.

 

Option D. Injection iron sucrose: Injection iron sucrose or any parenteral form is a first-line option. It is only indicated if the oral form is not tolerated or patient is not compliant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The comprehensive and cost-effective approach, including FeSO4 + Vitamin C + Folate + Vitamin B12, is preferable for the widespread prevention and treatment of anemia in a community setting, especially in a resource-limited Primary Health Center (PHC).

choices.text: Nothing as the child is already exposed

questions.text: Anuj has been diagnosed with diphtheria and is being treated in the ward. His 3-year-old brother, Ajay who lives in the same house has received vaccination against diphtheria about 16 months back. What is the next best step for the management of the younger sibling, Ajay? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Erythromycin only

 

In this case, the close contact of the patient is a 3-year-old child who had received the diphtheria vaccination 16 months ago, most likely as the 4th dose (1st booster). Therefore, only erythromycin is needed for prophylaxis.

 

It is crucial to monitor all household contacts for 7 days and obtain cultures from their nose and throat. Regardless of immunization status, all contacts should receive antibiotic prophylaxis such as benzathine penicillin G or erythromycin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. One booster dose: This is not necessary because the child had received the diphtheria vaccination 16 months ago, which should still provide adequate immunity.

 

Option B. Nothing as the child is already exposed: This is incorrect because close contacts need to be managed to prevent the spread of diphtheria, and antibiotic prophylaxis is recommended.

 

Option C. Erythromycin + diphtheria toxoid: This option is for those who have received less than three doses of diphtheria toxoid or have an unknown vaccination history. Since Ajay has been recently vaccinated, only erythromycin is needed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When Additional Toxoid is Needed:

  • <3 doses total received
  • >5 years since last dose
  • Unknown vaccination history
     

For a close contact of a diphtheria patient who has received the diphtheria vaccination within the last five years, antibiotic prophylaxis with erythromycin is the appropriate management step.

questions.text: A child with IQ of 50 comes under: (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mild MR

 

Mild MR is defined as an IQ of 50.

 

The MR is now replaced with Intellectual Disability.

 

IQ scores were used as the basis for the DSM IV (Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders) criteria for mental retardation:

 

  • The formula for calculating IQ is IQ = Mental age – Chronological age 100.
  • Typical IQ range: 90 to 110
  • 70 to 90 percent mental sub normality

 

The most common cause of MR is Down’s Syndrome.

 

Fragile X Syndrome- will also results in the MR.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Moderate MR: Moderate intellectual disability refers to an IQ range of 35-50, which is lower than the child’s IQ in this case.

 

Option C. Severe MR: Severe intellectual disability corresponds to an IQ range of 20-35. Children with this level of disability require substantial support for daily activities.

 

Option D. Profound MR: Profound intellectual disability refers to an IQ score below 20. Individuals with this level of disability need complete care and supervision throughout their life.

 

Educational Objective:


Mild intellectual disability is defined as an IQ range of 50-70, and children with mild intellectual disability can often live independently with some support.
